Variance swap

A variance swap with maturity T is a contract which pays out the realized variance of the logarithmic total returns up to T less a strike called the variance swap rate V0Tâ€‹, determined in such a way that the contract has zero value today.

3.2.1 two-step approach: é€ç‚¹è®­ç»ƒï¼ˆpointwiseï¼‰å’ŒåŸºäºç½‘æ ¼(grid-based)è®­ç»ƒ

In this section, we examine its advantages and present an analysis of the objective function with the goal to enhance learning performance. Within this framework, the pointwise approach has the ability to asses the quality of P using Monte Carlo or PDE methods, and indeed it is superior training in terms of robustness.

Pointwise learning

1.2 The approximation scheme

We now move on to the core of the project, namely an approximation scheme for the system (1.3). The basic ingredient to construct approximating sequences is a family of iid random variables, which satisfies the following assumption: Assumption 1.6. The family (Î¾iâ€‹)iâ‰¥1â€‹ forms an iid sequence of centered random variables with finite moments of all orders and E[Î¾12â€‹]=Ïƒ2>0

The construction of the proof allows to extend the convergence to the case where Y is a d-dimensional diffusion without additional work. The proof of the theorem requires a certain number of steps: we start with the convergence of the approximation (Ynâ€‹) in some HÃ¶lder space, which we translate, first into convergence of the stochastic integral in (1.3), then, by continuity of the mapping Î¦, into convergence of the sequence (Î¦(GÎ±Ynâ€‹)). 1.3. Monte-Carlo.

Theorem 1.7 introduces the theoretical foundations of Monte-Carlo methods (in particular for path-dependent options) for rough volatility models. For the numerical recipe to be as general as possible, we shall consider the general time partition T:={tiâ€‹=niTâ€‹}i=0,â€¦,nâ€‹ on [0,T] with T>0.

1.3.1 Enhancing performance. A standard practice in Monte-Carlo simulation is to match moments of the approximating sequence with the target process. In particular, when the process is Gaussian, matching first and second moments suffices. We only illustrate this approximation for Brownian motion: the left-point approximation may be modified to match moments as (GÎ±W)(tiâ€‹)â‰ˆÏƒnâ€‹1â€‹k=1âˆ‘iâ€‹g(tkâˆ—â€‹)Î¶kâ€‹,Â forÂ i=0,â€¦,n(1.8) where tkâˆ—â€‹ is chosen optimally. Since the kernel g(â‹…) is deterministic, there is no confusion with the Stratonovich stochastic integral, and the resulting approximation will always converge to the ItÃ´ integral. The first two moments of GÎ±W read E((GÎ±W)(t))=0Â andÂ V((GÎ±W)(t))=âˆ«0tâ€‹g(tâˆ’s)2Â ds The first moment of the approximating sequence 1.8 is always zero, and the second moment reads V(Ïƒnâ€‹1â€‹k=1âˆ‘jâˆ’1â€‹g(tkâˆ—â€‹)Î¶kâ€‹)=n1â€‹k=1âˆ‘jâˆ’1â€‹g(tkâˆ—â€‹)2 Equating the theoretical and approximating quantities we obtain n1â€‹g(tkâˆ—â€‹)2Â ds=âˆ«tkâˆ’1â€‹tkâ€‹â€‹g(tâˆ’s)2Â ds for k=1,â€¦,n, so that the optimal evaluation point can be computed as g(tkâˆ—â€‹)=nâˆ«tkâˆ’1â€‹tkâ€‹â€‹g(tâˆ’s)2Â dsâ€‹,Â forÂ anyÂ k=1,â€¦,n In the Riemann-Liouville fractional Brownian motion case, g(u)=uHâˆ’1/2, and the optimal point can be computed in closed form as tkâˆ—â€‹=(2Hnâ€‹[(tâˆ’tkâˆ’1â€‹)2Hâˆ’(tâˆ’tkâ€‹)2H])1/(2Hâˆ’1),Â forÂ eachÂ k=1,â€¦,n

1.3.2 Reducing Variance.

As Bayer, Friz and Gatheral, a major drawback in simulating rough volatility models is the very high variance of the estimators, so that a large number of simulations are needed to produce a decent price estimate. Nevertheless, the rDonsker scheme admits a very simple conditional expectation technique which reduces both memory requirements and variance while also admitting antithetic variates. This approach is best suited for calibrating European type options. We consider FtBâ€‹=Ïƒ(Bsâ€‹:sâ‰¤t) and FtWâ€‹=Ïƒ(Wsâ€‹:sâ‰¤t) the natural filtrations generated by the Brownian motions B and W. In particular the conditional variance process Vtâ€‹âˆ£FtWâ€‹ is deterministic. As discussed by Romano and Touzi, and recently adapted to the rBergomi case by McCrickerd and Pakkanen, we can decompose the stock price process as eXtâ€‹=E(Ïâˆ«0tâ€‹Î¦(GÎ±Y)(s)â€‹dBsâ€‹)E(1âˆ’Ï2â€‹âˆ«0tâ€‹Î¦(GÎ±Y)(s)â€‹dBsâŠ¥â€‹):=eXt1â€‹eXt2â€‹ and notice that Xtâ€‹âˆ£(FtWâ€‹âˆ§F0Bâ€‹)âˆ¼N(Xt1â€‹âˆ’(1âˆ’Ï2)âˆ«0tâ€‹Î¦(GÎ±Y)(s)ds,(1âˆ’Ï2)âˆ«0tâ€‹Î¦(GÎ±Y)(s)ds) Thus exp(Xtâ€‹) becomes log-normal and the Black-Scholes closed-form formulae are valid here (European, Barrier options, maximum,...). The advantage of this approach is that the orthogonal Brownian motion BâŠ¥ is completely unnecessary for the simulation, hence the generation of random numbers is reduced to a half, yielding proportional memory saving. Not only this, but also this simple trick reduces the variance of the Monte-Carlo estimate, hence fewer simulations are needed to obtain the same precision. We present a simple algorithm to implement the rDonsker with conditional expectation and assuming that Y=W.

Algorithm 1.9 (Simulation of rough volatility models with Brownian drivers). Consider the equidistant grid T. (1) Draw a random matrix {Î¶j,iâ€‹}j=1,â€¦,M/2â€‹ with unit variance, and create antithetic variates {âˆ’Î¶j,iâ€‹}j=1,â€¦,M/2â€‹; (2) Create a correlated matrix {Î¾j,iâ€‹} as above; (3) Simulate M paths of the fractional driving process GÎ±W using discrete convolution: (GÎ±W)j(T)=nTâ€‹â€‹(gâˆ—Î¶jâ€‹),j=1,â€¦,M and store in memory (1âˆ’Ï2)âˆ«0Tâ€‹(GÎ±W)j(s)dsâ‰ˆ(1âˆ’Ï2)nTâ€‹âˆ‘k=0nâˆ’1â€‹(GÎ±W)j(tkâ€‹)=:Î£j for each j=1,â€¦,M (4) use the forward Euler scheme to simulate the log-stock process, for each i=1,â€¦,n,j=1,â€¦,M, as Xj(tiâ€‹)=Xj(tiâˆ’1â€‹)âˆ’2Ï2â€‹nTâ€‹k=1âˆ‘iâ€‹Î¦(GÎ±W)j(tkâˆ’1â€‹)+ÏnTâ€‹â€‹k=1âˆ‘iâ€‹Î¦(GÎ±W)j(tkâˆ’1â€‹)â€‹Î¾j,iâ€‹ (5) Finally, we have Xj(T)âˆ¼N(XTjâ€‹âˆ’Î£j,Î£j) for j=1,â€¦,M; we may compute any option using the Black-Scholes formula. For instance a Call option with strike K would be given by Cj(K)= exp(XTjâ€‹)N(d1jâ€‹)âˆ’KN(d2jâ€‹) for j=1,â€¦,M, where d1jâ€‹:=Î£jâ€‹1â€‹(XTjâ€‹âˆ’log(K)+21â€‹Î£j) and d2jâ€‹=d1jâ€‹âˆ’Î£jâ€‹ Thus, the output of the model would be C(K)=M1â€‹âˆ‘k=1Mâ€‹Cj(K)

The algorithm is easily adapted to the case of general diffusions Y as drivers of the volatility (see Algorithm 1.8 step 2). Algorithm 1.8 is obviously faster than 1.9, especially when using control variates. Nevertheless, with the same number of paths, Algorithm 1.9 remarkably reduces the Monte-Carlo variance, meaning in turn that fewer simulations are needed, making it very competitive for calibration.

2.ä¼ ç»Ÿcholeskyåˆ†è§£æ³•æ¨¡æ‹Ÿ

If you need to generate n correlated Gaussian distributed random variables Yâˆ¼N(Î¼,Î£) where Y=(Y1â€‹,â€¦,Ynâ€‹) is the vector you want to simulate, Î¼=(Î¼1â€‹,â€¦,Î¼nâ€‹) the vector of means and Î£ the given covariance matrix, 1.you first need to simulate a vector of uncorrelated Gaussian random variables, Z 2.then find a square root of Î£, i.e. a matrix C such that CCâŠ¤=Î£. Your target vector is given by Y=Î¼+CZ A popular choice to calculate C is the Cholesky decomposition.

è€Œå¯¹äºæœ¬ rBergomi æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œ Stâ€‹vuâ€‹â€‹=S0â€‹E(âˆ«0tâ€‹vuâ€‹â€‹Â dZuâ€‹)=Î¾0â€‹(u)E(Î·2Hâ€‹âˆ«0uâ€‹(uâˆ’s)Î³1â€‹dWsâ€‹)=Î¾0â€‹(u)E(Î·W~uâ€‹)â€‹

where W~ is a Volterra processt with the scaling property Var[W~uâ€‹]=u2H. So far W~ behaves just like fBm. However, the dependence structure is different. Specifically, for v>u E[W~vâ€‹W~uâ€‹]=u2HG(uvâ€‹) where, for xâ‰¥1 and with Î³=1/2âˆ’H, G(x)â€‹=2Hâˆ«01â€‹(1âˆ’s)Î³(xâˆ’s)Î³dsâ€‹=1âˆ’Î³1âˆ’2Î³â€‹xÎ³2â€‹F1â€‹(1,Î³,2âˆ’Î³,x)â€‹ where 2â€‹F1â€‹(â‹…) denotes the confluent hypergeometric function. Remark 4.1 The dependence structure of the Volterra process W~ is markedly different from that of fBm with the MolchanGolosov kernel K(u,s) given by K(u,s)=cHâ€‹(uâˆ’s)Î³1â€‹2â€‹F1â€‹(1/2âˆ’H,Hâˆ’1/2,H+1/2,ssâˆ’uâ€‹)0<s<tâ€‹ for some constant cHâ€‹. In particular, for small H, correlations drop precipitously as the ratio u/v moves away from 1 .

We also need covariances of the Brownian motion Z with the Volterra process W~. With vâ‰¥u, these are given by E[W~vâ€‹Zuâ€‹]=ÏDHâ€‹{vH+1/2âˆ’(vâˆ’u)H+1/2} and E[Zvâ€‹W~uâ€‹]=ÏDHâ€‹uH+1/2 where for future convenience, we have defined the constant, DHâ€‹=H+1/22Hâ€‹â€‹ These two formulae may be conveniently combined as E[W~vâ€‹Zuâ€‹]=ÏDHâ€‹{vH+1/2âˆ’(vâˆ’min(u,v))H+1/2} Lastly, of course, for vâ‰¥u,E[Zvâ€‹Zuâ€‹]=u. With m the number of time steps and n the number of simulations, our rBergomi model simulation algorithm may then be summarized as follows.

  • Construct the joint covariance matrix for the Volterra process W~ and the Brownian motion Z and compute its Cholesky decomposition.
  • For each time, generate iid normal random vectors and multiply them by the lower triangular matrix obtained by the Cholesky decomposition to get a mÃ—2n matrix of paths of W~ and Z with the correct joint marginals.
  • With these paths held in memory, we may evaluate the expectation under Q of any payoff of interest.

we simulate the process âˆ«0tâ€‹(tâˆ’s)Hâˆ’1/2dWsâ€‹

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import scipy.special as special
def fBm_path_chol(grid_points, M, H, T):
    """
    @grid_points: # points in the simulation grid
    @H: Hurst Index
    @T: time horizon
    @M: # paths to simulate
    """
    
    assert 0<H<1.0
    
    ## Step1: create partition 
    
    X=np.linspace(0, 1, num=grid_points)
    
    # get rid of starting point
    X=X[1:grid_points]
    
    ## Step 2: compute covariance matrix
    Sigma=np.zeros((grid_points-1,grid_points-1))
    for j in range(grid_points-1):
        for i in range(grid_points-1):
            if i==j:
                Sigma[i,j]=np.power(X[i],2*H)/2/H
            else:
                s=np.minimum(X[i],X[j])
                t=np.maximum(X[i],X[j])
                Sigma[i,j]=np.power(t-s,H-0.5)/(H+0.5)*np.power(s,0.5+H)*special.hyp2f1(0.5-H, 0.5+H, 1.5+H, -s/(t-s))
        
    ## Step 3: compute Cholesky decomposition
    
    P=np.linalg.cholesky(Sigma)
    
    ## Step 4: draw Gaussian rv
    
    Z=np.random.normal(loc=0.0, scale=1.0, size=[M,grid_points-1])
    
    ## Step 5: get V
    
    W=np.zeros((M,grid_points))
    for i in range(M):
        W[i,1:grid_points]=np.dot(P,Z[i,:])
        
    #Use self-similarity to extend to [0,T] 
    
    return W*np.power(T,H)

3.rDonkeræ–¹æ³•

def fBm_path_rDonsker(grid_points, M, H, T, kernel="optimal"):
    """
    @grid_points: # points in the simulation grid
    @H: Hurst Index
    @T: time horizon
    @M: # paths to simulate
    @kernel: kernel evaluation point use "optimal" for momen-match or "naive" for left-point
    """
    
    assert 0<H<1.0
    
    ## Step1: create partition 
    dt=1./(grid_points-1)
    X=np.linspace(0, 1, num=grid_points)
    
    # get rid of starting point
    X=X[1:grid_points]
    
    ## Step 2: Draw random variables
    
    dW = np.power(dt, H) *np.random.normal(loc=0, scale=1, size=[M, grid_points-1])
        
    ## Step 3: compute the kernel evaluation points
    i=np.arange(grid_points-1) + 1
    # By default use optimal moment-matching
    if kernel=="optimal":
        opt_k=np.power((np.power(i,2*H)-np.power(i-1.,2*H))/2.0/H,0.5)
    # Alternatively use left-point evaluation
    elif kernel=="naive" : 
        opt_k=np.power(i,H-0.5)
    else:
        raise NameError("That was not a valid kernel")
    
    
    ## Step 4: Compute the convolution
    
    Y = np.zeros([M, n])
    for i in range(int(M)):
        Y[i, 1:n] = np.convolve(opt_k, dW[i, :])[0:n - 1]
        
    #Use self-similarity to extend to [0,T] 
    
    return Y*np.power(T,H)

2.1 Black&Scholes Delta Hedge

In many cases, of local stochastic volatility models as of form (1.1) and options depending only on the terminal value of the price process, a Delta hedge of the BlackÃ¢Ä‚ÅScholes model works well.

ä»¤ C=g(STâ€‹) ï¼Œ Ï€BSgâ€‹(t,T,s,Ïƒ) æ˜¯ BS æ¨¡å‹ä¸‹ t æ—¶åˆ»çš„ä»·æ ¼ï¼å¯¹å†²ç­–ç•¥ä¸ºï¼š htâ€‹=âˆ‚sâ€‹Ï€BSgâ€‹(t,T,Stâ€‹,L(t,Stâ€‹)Î±tâ€‹)

2.2 Hedging Strategies as Neural Networks-Deep Hedging

åœ¨å¯¹å†²äº§å“æ•°å¾ˆå¤šç­‰æƒ…å†µä¸‹æ—¶ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å°†å¯¹å†²ç­–ç•¥ç”¨ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œå‚æ•°åŒ–ï¼ä»¤æœŸæƒçš„æ”¯ä»˜æ˜¯å¯¹å†²äº§å“æœ€ç»ˆä»·å€¼çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œi.e.ï¼ŒC=g(ZTâ€‹)ï¼åœ¨é©¬å°”ç§‘å¤«æ¨¡å‹ä¸­ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç”¨å‡½æ•°è¡¨ç¤ºå¯¹å†²ç­–ç•¥ï¼š h:R+â€‹Ã—Rrâ†’Rr,htâ€‹=h(t,z) å¯¹åº”è¿™æ ·ä¸€ä¸ªç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œï¼š(t,z)â†¦h(t,z,Î´)âˆˆNNr+1,râ€‹ï¼Î´ æ˜¯ç½‘ç»œå‚æ•°ï¼æ ¹æ®Buehler H, Gonon L, Teichmann J, et al. Deep hedging[J].
